page.title: 10 MELIDEN CHURCH
page.content: There is little doubt that a church has existed on its present site from the earliest times.The earliest known record is contained in the{Domesday {Book A.D. 1086}.The church is situated at a natural focal point in the surrounding district,and is the only church in Wales dedicated to{St. Melyd who came to Britain in{601,}became {first Bishop}of{London}in {604}and {Archbishop}of{Canterbury 619}.The chu- rch recorded in{Domesday}would almost certainly have been of timber.The pre- sent stone structure has parts dating from{13.C.,14.C.,15.C.}The rectangular plan is typical of many churches built in Wales during that period.The long narrow nave ends in the square-ended chancel,with a porch on the south side.Major restoration was carried out in{1885}.Today the church is an important centre for village life.
